title: How to Make Simple Muffins

steps.headline: Pre-heat the oven to 400˚F/204˚C.
Prepare the muffin pan with liners or spray.
steps.description: Place paper liners in the cups of a regular-sized muffin pan, or spray each cup with non-stick vegetable oil and set aside. Liners will make clean-up quick and efficient. You can also spray the inside of the liners to make removing the muffins easier. If you prefer your muffins to have a bit of a crust use a spray instead of liners.

steps.headline: Measure the flour properly.
steps.description: Use a spoon to fluff up the flour in the bag and then scoop it into a 1 cup (240 ml) dry measuring cup, but don’t pack it down. When it’s just overflowing, take the straight-edged side of a knife and smooth it across the measuring cup. You’ll end up using far more flour than a recipe calls for if you scoop flour from the bag with the measuring cup or if you pack it down, which will make muffins dry and hard.

steps.headline: Combine the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium-sized mixing bowl.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon to mix them together well, and then spin the spoon to create a well in the center where you will pour the wet ingredients. Making bread-like muffins that are light and crumble easily utilize what’s called the muffin method, in which you mix the dry and wet ingredients separately and then barely stir – never use an electric mixer – the two together so the gluten in the flour isn’t over-activated. The well will help ensure you don’t over-mix the two, the chief mistake to avoid when making muffins. Over-mixing will make muffins dense and tough.

steps.headline: Next mix the oil, milk and egg.
steps.description: First crack the egg on the edge of a small bowl, empty it into the bowl and check for eggshells. If you see any, use a fork to dig them out. Then use a whisk, electric mixer or fork to combine the oil, milk and egg in a medium-sized mixing bowl.

steps.headline: Pour the wet ingredients into the dry.
steps.description: As soon as you pour the wet ingredients into the well of the dry, use a wooden spoon to mix them, but only until the dry ingredients are just barely moistened. The rule of thumb is to use between 10-15 strokes. The batter will be lumpy, and you may even see traces of flour. This is what you want. Over-mixing causes long strands of gluten in the flour to develop, creating not only the toughness you want to avoid but also tunnels in muffins.

steps.headline: Scoop the batter into muffin cups immediately.
steps.description: Never let muffin batter rest because the baking powder will lose its leavening power, which is what makes baked goods rise. Use either a spoon or an ice scream scooper and fill each cup 2/3 full. If you fill each cup all the way, the muffins will end up flat, not domed. If you’re using a muffin pan that has more than 12 cups, spread out the batter so it’s not concentrated in one area. Then fill the empty cups halfway full with water.

steps.headline: Bake the batter.
steps.description: Place the muffin pan in the center rack of the oven for even heating and bake for 20-25 minutes. Rotate the pan about halfway through the baking time.

steps.headline: Check at 20 minutes to see if they’re done.
steps.description: Stick a toothpick in the center of a few muffins to see if the muffins are fully baked. If the toothpick is clean when you remove it, your muffins are ready. If not, continue cooking another five minutes and check again. When bread-like muffins have fully baked, they should be golden brown and have a rounded, pebbly top.

steps.headline: Remove the muffins and cool them in the pan for 5-10 minutes.
steps.description: Take the pan from the oven, put it on a cooling rack and let the muffins cool so they won’t break when you remove them from the pan. Then use a butter knife to lift the muffins from the cups and place them on the cooling rack. Make sure you use oven mitts or gloves, or folded towels, to protect your hands from being burned when you remove the pan.

steps.headline: Serve them now or wrap cooled muffins individually in plastic wrap and freeze.
steps.description: You can also top them with yogurt, cream cheese, butter, a drizzle of white chocolate or whipped cream! Thaw them at room temperature before eating if you decide to freeze them.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 375°F/190°C.
Prep the muffin pan.
steps.description: Either spray a regular-sized, 12-cup muffin pan with non-stick vegetable spray or put muffin or cupcake liners, which can also be sprayed, in each cup.

steps.headline: Mix the butter and sugar with an electric mixer until it’s light and fluffy.
steps.description: Beat them together in a large mixing bowl on a medium speed for several minutes. You shouldn’t be able to see any sugar granules once done. Cake-like muffins use what’s called the creaming method, in which you mix the butter and sugar before adding the egg(s), mix the remaining dry ingredients separately and then combine the two alternately with the milk. These recipes always call for more butter and sugar to act as tenderizers and minimize gluten development in the flour so muffins don’t become tough. This, along with how the sugar creates small air holes in the butter when creamed, makes the muffins moist and light.

steps.headline: Add the egg to the sugar and butter mixture.
steps.description: After you’ve cracked the egg in a separate bowl and removed any stray pieces of eggshell, use an electric mixer on a medium speed to beat the egg into the butter and sugar mixture. Then set it aside.

steps.headline: Stir together the remaining dry ingredients.
steps.description: Because you've already used the sugar, now mix the flour, baking soda and salt with a wooden spoon in a medium-sized bowl.

steps.headline: Combine the milk with both wet and dry mixtures alternately.
steps.description: First add some of the dry mixture to the wet mixture and stir with a wooden spoon just until the dry ingredients are coated. Then add about half of the milk and stir until the batter becomes slightly moist. Repeat until everything is mixed and smooth. As with bread-like muffins, you don’t want to over-mix, but you will have to use more than 10-15 strokes to combine the ingredients in this last stage of mixing.

steps.headline: Spoon the batter into muffin cups.
steps.description: Use either a spoon or an ice cream scooper and immediately fill the cups 2/3 full so the leavening agent – the baking powder – still has enough “kick” to make the muffins rise. Don’t fully fill the cups so the muffins have a nice domed shape.

steps.headline: Bake the muffins for 20-25 minutes.
steps.description: Place the pan in the center rack of the oven for consistent and even heat distribution. Some muffin pans have a very dark pre-coating. If yours does, reduce the oven temperature by 25˚F as darker-colored pans absorb more heat, therefore becoming hotter and transmitting more heat to what’s baking inside. Rotate the pan midway through baking to ensure they’re baking evenly and to adjust the oven temperature if needed.

steps.headline: Check to see if they’re done after 25 minutes.
steps.description: Stick a toothpick in the center of a few muffins. The muffins are ready if nothing is sticking to the toothpick when you remove it. Put them back in and bake another five minutes if they're not quite done. Cake-like muffins should be golden brown with smooth tops.

steps.headline: Remove the pan from the oven and let the muffins cool.
steps.description: Place the pan on a cooling rack for 10-15 minutes before gently removing each muffin with a butter knife and placing it on the cooling rack.

steps.headline: Eat them while they're nice and warm or freeze for later!
Preheat the oven to 375°F/190°C.
Get the muffin pan ready.
steps.description: You can either spray the cups of a 12-cup, regular-sized muffin or cupcake pan with non-stick vegetable oil, or you can put paper liners in each of the cups. If the muffin pan has more than 12 cups, fill those you won’t use halfway with water. Choose cups in different spots so the muffins will bake evenly. You can also use foil liners; however, they tend to retain heat, so you may need to adjust your oven temperature or cooking time.

steps.headline: Combine the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon to mix together the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium-sized mixing bowl. Ensure you scoop flour into the measuring cup without packing it down before leveling if off with a knife. You can also use a sifter or strainer before measuring the flour if it has become packed down in the bag.

steps.headline: Whisk together the sugar, butter, milk and eggs.
steps.description: In a separate, medium-sized mixing bowl, use a whisk, electric mixer or a fork to mix everything until it's well blended. You shouldn’t be able to see any streaks of egg.

steps.headline: Combine the wet and dry mixtures.
steps.description: Use the wooden spoon to mix the two, using only 10-15 strokes, so you don’t over-mix and end up with tough muffins with tunnels from over-activating the flour’s gluten.

steps.headline: Fold the blueberries into the batter.
steps.description: Pour the blueberries into the center of the batter. Take a large, soft spatula and gently go along the side of the bowl to the bottom and bring the batter to the top, covering the blueberries. Do this 3-4 times so the blueberries don’t crush and bleed into the batter. You can also dust the blueberries in flour before adding them to help prevent bleeding. Blueberries are just one of many things you can add to your muffins to change or add flavor. You can also easily make muffins with a variety of spices, fruits, nuts, oats, creams and glazes.

steps.headline: Fill the muffin cups and sprinkle each with turbinado sugar.
steps.description: Using a spoon or ice cream scooper, fill each cup only 2/3 full with batter so they will have nicely domed tops. You can also wait until the last 10 minutes before sprinkling on the turbinado sugar.

steps.headline: Put the pan in the center rack of the oven and bake for 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Rotate the pan halfway through backing, particularly if one side seems to be getting done faster than another.

steps.headline: Check them at 20 minutes.
steps.description: Insert a toothpick in the center of several muffins and, if it’s clean when you remove it, they’re done. Otherwise continue baking another 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Take the pan out of the oven and put it on a cooling rack.
steps.description: Let the muffins cool for 5-10 minutes in the pan before using a butter knife to carefully remove them from the pan and transfer them to the cooling rack.

steps.headline: Polish them off now while they're freshly baked or freeze them individually in plastic wrap for breakfast on-the-go!

text: Bread-Like Simple Muffins Pre-heat the oven to 400˚F/204˚C.  Prepare the muffin pan with liners or spray. Place paper liners in the cups of a regular-sized muffin pan, or spray each cup with non-stick vegetable oil and set aside. Liners will make clean-up quick and efficient. You can also spray the inside of the liners to make removing the muffins easier. If you prefer your muffins to have a bit of a crust use a spray instead of liners. Measure the flour properly. Use a spoon to fluff up the flour in the bag and then scoop it into a 1 cup (240 ml) dry measuring cup, but don’t pack it down. When it’s just overflowing, take the straight-edged side of a knife and smooth it across the measuring cup. You’ll end up using far more flour than a recipe calls for if you scoop flour from the bag with the measuring cup or if you pack it down, which will make muffins dry and hard. Combine the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium-sized mixing bowl. Use a wooden spoon to mix them together well, and then spin the spoon to create a well in the center where you will pour the wet ingredients. Making bread-like muffins that are light and crumble easily utilize what’s called the muffin method, in which you mix the dry and wet ingredients separately and then barely stir – never use an electric mixer – the two together so the gluten in the flour isn’t over-activated. The well will help ensure you don’t over-mix the two, the chief mistake to avoid when making muffins. Over-mixing will make muffins dense and tough. Next mix the oil, milk and egg. First crack the egg on the edge of a small bowl, empty it into the bowl and check for eggshells. If you see any, use a fork to dig them out. Then use a whisk, electric mixer or fork to combine the oil, milk and egg in a medium-sized mixing bowl. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry. As soon as you pour the wet ingredients into the well of the dry, use a wooden spoon to mix them, but only until the dry ingredients are just barely moistened. The rule of thumb is to use between 10-15 strokes. The batter will be lumpy, and you may even see traces of flour. This is what you want. Over-mixing causes long strands of gluten in the flour to develop, creating not only the toughness you want to avoid but also tunnels in muffins. Scoop the batter into muffin cups immediately. Never let muffin batter rest because the baking powder will lose its leavening power, which is what makes baked goods rise. Use either a spoon or an ice scream scooper and fill each cup 2/3 full. If you fill each cup all the way, the muffins will end up flat, not domed. If you’re using a muffin pan that has more than 12 cups, spread out the batter so it’s not concentrated in one area. Then fill the empty cups halfway full with water. Bake the batter. Place the muffin pan in the center rack of the oven for even heating and bake for 20-25 minutes. Rotate the pan about halfway through the baking time. Check at 20 minutes to see if they’re done. Stick a toothpick in the center of a few muffins to see if the muffins are fully baked. If the toothpick is clean when you remove it, your muffins are ready. If not, continue cooking another five minutes and check again. When bread-like muffins have fully baked, they should be golden brown and have a rounded, pebbly top. Remove the muffins and cool them in the pan for 5-10 minutes. Take the pan from the oven, put it on a cooling rack and let the muffins cool so they won’t break when you remove them from the pan. Then use a butter knife to lift the muffins from the cups and place them on the cooling rack. Make sure you use oven mitts or gloves, or folded towels, to protect your hands from being burned when you remove the pan. Serve them now or wrap cooled muffins individually in plastic wrap and freeze. You can also top them with yogurt, cream cheese, butter, a drizzle of white chocolate or whipped cream! Thaw them at room temperature before eating if you decide to freeze them. Cake-Like Simple Muffins Preheat the oven to 375°F/190°C.  Prep the muffin pan. Either spray a regular-sized, 12-cup muffin pan with non-stick vegetable spray or put muffin or cupcake liners, which can also be sprayed, in each cup. Mix the butter and sugar with an electric mixer until it’s light and fluffy. Beat them together in a large mixing bowl on a medium speed for several minutes. You shouldn’t be able to see any sugar granules once done. Cake-like muffins use what’s called the creaming method, in which you mix the butter and sugar before adding the egg(s), mix the remaining dry ingredients separately and then combine the two alternately with the milk. These recipes always call for more butter and sugar to act as tenderizers and minimize gluten development in the flour so muffins don’t become tough. This, along with how the sugar creates small air holes in the butter when creamed, makes the muffins moist and light. Add the egg to the sugar and butter mixture. After you’ve cracked the egg in a separate bowl and removed any stray pieces of eggshell, use an electric mixer on a medium speed to beat the egg into the butter and sugar mixture. Then set it aside. Stir together the remaining dry ingredients. Because you've already used the sugar, now mix the flour, baking soda and salt with a wooden spoon in a medium-sized bowl. Combine the milk with both wet and dry mixtures alternately. First add some of the dry mixture to the wet mixture and stir with a wooden spoon just until the dry ingredients are coated. Then add about half of the milk and stir until the batter becomes slightly moist. Repeat until everything is mixed and smooth. As with bread-like muffins, you don’t want to over-mix, but you will have to use more than 10-15 strokes to combine the ingredients in this last stage of mixing. Spoon the batter into muffin cups. Use either a spoon or an ice cream scooper and immediately fill the cups 2/3 full so the leavening agent – the baking powder – still has enough “kick” to make the muffins rise. Don’t fully fill the cups so the muffins have a nice domed shape. Bake the muffins for 20-25 minutes. Place the pan in the center rack of the oven for consistent and even heat distribution. Some muffin pans have a very dark pre-coating. If yours does, reduce the oven temperature by 25˚F as darker-colored pans absorb more heat, therefore becoming hotter and transmitting more heat to what’s baking inside. Rotate the pan midway through baking to ensure they’re baking evenly and to adjust the oven temperature if needed. Check to see if they’re done after 25 minutes. Stick a toothpick in the center of a few muffins. The muffins are ready if nothing is sticking to the toothpick when you remove it. Put them back in and bake another five minutes if they're not quite done. Cake-like muffins should be golden brown with smooth tops. Remove the pan from the oven and let the muffins cool. Place the pan on a cooling rack for 10-15 minutes before gently removing each muffin with a butter knife and placing it on the cooling rack. Eat them while they're nice and warm or freeze for later!  Simple Blueberry Muffins Preheat the oven to 375°F/190°C.  Get the muffin pan ready. You can either spray the cups of a 12-cup, regular-sized muffin or cupcake pan with non-stick vegetable oil, or you can put paper liners in each of the cups. If the muffin pan has more than 12 cups, fill those you won’t use halfway with water. Choose cups in different spots so the muffins will bake evenly. You can also use foil liners; however, they tend to retain heat, so you may need to adjust your oven temperature or cooking time. Combine the dry ingredients. Use a wooden spoon to mix together the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium-sized mixing bowl. Ensure you scoop flour into the measuring cup without packing it down before leveling if off with a knife. You can also use a sifter or strainer before measuring the flour if it has become packed down in the bag. Whisk together the sugar, butter, milk and eggs. In a separate, medium-sized mixing bowl, use a whisk, electric mixer or a fork to mix everything until it's well blended. You shouldn’t be able to see any streaks of egg. Combine the wet and dry mixtures. Use the wooden spoon to mix the two, using only 10-15 strokes, so you don’t over-mix and end up with tough muffins with tunnels from over-activating the flour’s gluten. Fold the blueberries into the batter. Pour the blueberries into the center of the batter. Take a large, soft spatula and gently go along the side of the bowl to the bottom and bring the batter to the top, covering the blueberries. Do this 3-4 times so the blueberries don’t crush and bleed into the batter. You can also dust the blueberries in flour before adding them to help prevent bleeding. Blueberries are just one of many things you can add to your muffins to change or add flavor. You can also easily make muffins with a variety of spices, fruits, nuts, oats, creams and glazes. Fill the muffin cups and sprinkle each with turbinado sugar. Using a spoon or ice cream scooper, fill each cup only 2/3 full with batter so they will have nicely domed tops. You can also wait until the last 10 minutes before sprinkling on the turbinado sugar. Put the pan in the center rack of the oven and bake for 20 to 25 minutes. Rotate the pan halfway through backing, particularly if one side seems to be getting done faster than another. Check them at 20 minutes. Insert a toothpick in the center of several muffins and, if it’s clean when you remove it, they’re done. Otherwise continue baking another 5 minutes. Take the pan out of the oven and put it on a cooling rack. Let the muffins cool for 5-10 minutes in the pan before using a butter knife to carefully remove them from the pan and transfer them to the cooling rack. Polish them off now while they're freshly baked or freeze them individually in plastic wrap for breakfast on-the-go!
sentences: Bread-Like Simple Muffins Pre-heat the oven to 400˚F/204˚C.
Prepare the muffin pan with liners or spray.
Place paper liners in the cups of a regular-sized muffin pan, or spray each cup with non-stick vegetable oil and set aside.
Liners will make clean-up quick and efficient.
You can also spray the inside of the liners to make removing the muffins easier.
If you prefer your muffins to have a bit of a crust use a spray instead of liners.
Measure the flour properly.
Use a spoon to fluff up the flour in the bag and then scoop it into a 1 cup (240 ml) dry measuring cup, but don’t pack it down.
When it’s just overflowing, take the straight-edged side of a knife and smooth it across the measuring cup.
You’ll end up using far more flour than a recipe calls for if you scoop flour from the bag with the measuring cup or if you pack it down, which will make muffins dry and hard.
Combine the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium-sized mixing bowl.
Use a wooden spoon to mix them together well, and then spin the spoon to create a well in the center where you will pour the wet ingredients.

Making bread-like muffins that are light and crumble easily utilize what’s called the muffin method, in which you mix the dry and wet ingredients separately and then barely stir – never use an electric mixer – the two together so the gluten in the flour isn’t over-activated.
The well will help ensure you don’t over-mix the two, the chief mistake to avoid when making muffins.
Over-mixing will make muffins dense and tough.
Next mix the oil, milk and egg.
First crack the egg on the edge of a small bowl, empty it into the bowl and check for eggshells.
If you see any, use a fork to dig them out.
Then use a whisk, electric mixer or fork to combine the oil, milk and egg in a medium-sized mixing bowl.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry.
As soon as you pour the wet ingredients into the well of the dry, use a wooden spoon to mix them, but only until the dry ingredients are just barely moistened.
The rule of thumb is to use between 10-15 strokes.
The batter will be lumpy, and you may even see traces of flour.
This is what you want.
Over-mixing causes long strands of gluten in the flour to develop, creating not only the toughness you want to avoid but also tunnels in muffins.
Scoop the batter into muffin cups immediately.
Never let muffin batter rest because the baking powder will lose its leavening power, which is what makes baked goods rise.
Use either a spoon or an ice scream scooper and fill each cup 2/3 full.
If you fill each cup all the way, the muffins will end up flat, not domed.
If you’re using a muffin pan that has more than 12 cups, spread out the batter so it’s not concentrated in one area.
Then fill the empty cups halfway full with water.
Bake the batter.
Place the muffin pan in the center rack of the oven for even heating and bake for 20-25 minutes.
Rotate the pan about halfway through the baking time.
Check at 20 minutes to see if they’re done.
Stick a toothpick in the center of a few muffins to see if the muffins are fully baked.
If the toothpick is clean when you remove it, your muffins are ready.
If not, continue cooking another five minutes and check again.
When bread-like muffins have fully baked, they should be golden brown and have a rounded, pebbly top.
Remove the muffins and cool them in the pan for 5-10 minutes.
Take the pan from the oven, put it on a cooling rack and let the muffins cool so they won’t break when you remove them from the pan.
Then use a butter knife to lift the muffins from the cups and place them on the cooling rack.
Make sure you use oven mitts or gloves, or folded towels, to protect your hands from being burned when you remove the pan.
Serve them now or wrap cooled muffins individually in plastic wrap and freeze.
You can also top them with yogurt, cream cheese, butter, a drizzle of white chocolate or whipped cream!
Thaw them at room temperature before eating if you decide to freeze them.
Cake-Like Simple Muffins Preheat the oven to 375°F/190°C.
Prep the muffin pan.
Either spray a regular-sized, 12-cup muffin pan with non-stick vegetable spray or put muffin or cupcake liners, which can also be sprayed, in each cup.
Mix the butter and sugar with an electric mixer until it’s light and fluffy.
Beat them together in a large mixing bowl on a medium speed for several minutes.
You shouldn’t be able to see any sugar granules once done.

Cake-like muffins use what’s called the creaming method, in which you mix the butter and sugar before adding the egg(s), mix the remaining dry ingredients separately and then combine the two alternately with the milk.
These recipes always call for more butter and sugar to act as tenderizers and minimize gluten development in the flour so muffins don’t become tough.
This, along with how the sugar creates small air holes in the butter when creamed, makes the muffins moist and light.
Add the egg to the sugar and butter mixture.
After you’ve cracked the egg in a separate bowl and removed any stray pieces of eggshell, use an electric mixer on a medium speed to beat the egg into the butter and sugar mixture.
Then set it aside.
Stir together the remaining dry ingredients.
Because you've already used the sugar, now mix the flour, baking soda and salt with a wooden spoon in a medium-sized bowl.
Combine the milk with both wet and dry mixtures alternately.
First add some of the dry mixture to the wet mixture and stir with a wooden spoon just until the dry ingredients are coated.
Then add about half of the milk and stir until the batter becomes slightly moist.
Repeat until everything is mixed and smooth.
As with bread-like muffins, you don’t want to over-mix, but you will have to use more than 10-15 strokes to combine the ingredients in this last stage of mixing.
Spoon the batter into muffin cups.
Use either a spoon or an ice cream scooper and immediately fill the cups 2/3 full so the leavening agent – the baking powder – still has enough “kick” to make the muffins rise.
Don’t fully fill the cups so the muffins have a nice domed shape.
Bake the muffins for 20-25 minutes.
Place the pan in the center rack of the oven for consistent and even heat distribution.
Some muffin pans have a very dark pre-coating.
If yours does, reduce the oven temperature by 25˚F as darker-colored pans absorb more heat, therefore becoming hotter and transmitting more heat to what’s baking inside.
Rotate the pan midway through baking to ensure they’re baking evenly and to adjust the oven temperature if needed.
Check to see if they’re done after 25 minutes.
Stick a toothpick in the center of a few muffins.
The muffins are ready if nothing is sticking to the toothpick when you remove it.
Put them back in and bake another five minutes if they're not quite done.
Cake-like muffins should be golden brown with smooth tops.
Remove the pan from the oven and let the muffins cool.
Place the pan on a cooling rack for 10-15 minutes before gently removing each muffin with a butter knife and placing it on the cooling rack.
Eat them while they're nice and warm or freeze for later!
Simple Blueberry Muffins Preheat the oven to 375°F/190°C.
Get the muffin pan ready.
You can either spray the cups of a 12-cup, regular-sized muffin or cupcake pan with non-stick vegetable oil, or you can put paper liners in each of the cups.
If the muffin pan has more than 12 cups, fill those you won’t use halfway with water.
Choose cups in different spots so the muffins will bake evenly.
You can also use foil liners; however, they tend to retain heat, so you may need to adjust your oven temperature or cooking time.
Combine the dry ingredients.
Use a wooden spoon to mix together the flour, sugar, baking powder and salt in a medium-sized mixing bowl.
Ensure you scoop flour into the measuring cup without packing it down before leveling if off with a knife.
You can also use a sifter or strainer before measuring the flour if it has become packed down in the bag.
Whisk together the sugar, butter, milk and eggs.
In a separate, medium-sized mixing bowl, use a whisk, electric mixer or a fork to mix everything until it's well blended.
You shouldn’t be able to see any streaks of egg.
Combine the wet and dry mixtures.
Use the wooden spoon to mix the two, using only 10-15 strokes, so you don’t over-mix and end up with tough muffins with tunnels from over-activating the flour’s gluten.
Fold the blueberries into the batter.
Pour the blueberries into the center of the batter.
Take a large, soft spatula and gently go along the side of the bowl to the bottom and bring the batter to the top, covering the blueberries.
Do this 3-4 times so the blueberries don’t crush and bleed into the batter.
You can also dust the blueberries in flour before adding them to help prevent bleeding.
Blueberries are just one of many things you can add to your muffins to change or add flavor.
You can also easily make muffins with a variety of spices, fruits, nuts, oats, creams and glazes.
Fill the muffin cups and sprinkle each with turbinado sugar.
Using a spoon or ice cream scooper, fill each cup only 2/3 full with batter so they will have nicely domed tops.
You can also wait until the last 10 minutes before sprinkling on the turbinado sugar.
Put the pan in the center rack of the oven and bake for 20 to 25 minutes.
Rotate the pan halfway through backing, particularly if one side seems to be getting done faster than another.
Check them at 20 minutes.
Insert a toothpick in the center of several muffins and, if it’s clean when you remove it, they’re done.
Otherwise continue baking another 5 minutes.
Take the pan out of the oven and put it on a cooling rack.
Let the muffins cool for 5-10 minutes in the pan before using a butter knife to carefully remove them from the pan and transfer them to the cooling rack.
Polish them off now while they're freshly baked or freeze them individually in plastic wrap for breakfast on-the-go!
tyn_section: 1 regular-sized cupcake or muffin pan with 12 cups
Paper muffin/cupcake liners or non-stick vegetable spray
